title: Changes in RANKL, OPG, and 25(OH)D Levels in Children with Leukemia from Diagnosis to Remission
content: Background: The receptor activator of the nuclear factor-kB (RANK)/RANK ligand (RANKL)/osteoprotegerin (OPG) pathway is a determining pathway in the balance between bone formation and resorption; disruptions in this complex can affect bone metabolism. Methods: This study analyzed the changes in RANKL, OPG and 25(OH)D levels, the RANKL/OPG ratio, and other bone turnover markers (BTM) from diagnosis to complete remission in children with acute lym-phoblastic leukemia (ALL). This is a prospective observational cohort study. This study was carried out in the Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social in Mexico City. Thirty-three patients (4-17 years) with newly diagnosed B-cell ALL were included. The patients were treated with the HP09 chemotherapy protocol. Children who had previously been treated with corticosteroids were excluded. A pe-ripheral blood sample at diagnosis and remission was collected to determine the 25(OH)D and BTM concentrations.
